Full Review: The game's shtick is that both the player and the monsters have built in bonuses and abilities, and both can carry weapons that give them additional bonuses and abilities. While the enemy's are usually fixed at spawn, the player can adjust theirs by equipping different weapons and polymorphing into monsters. It reminds me a bit of Desktop Dungeons in the sense that every floor can be viewed as a puzzle, where killing monsters in a certain order will maximize your survival while minimizing your expenditure of resources (levels, and thrown weapons). Without diving hard, I had a hard time getting past the 3rd level and I honestly can't tell if that's because the game is just poorly balanced or I lack the skill to play it effectively.

The difficulty is a bit low, though I can say if that was the intent or a balance problem and the enemy behavior is easy to game (waiting for a turn doesn't cost stamina, so entering a room and leaving to wait for the enemies to chase you down a corridor is a devastatingly effective tactic). It's a coffee break RL that is good for a play-through.

Innovation: 1 - Pretty graphics, but nothing new under the hood.
Scope: 2 - Low end of two, but making a RL that pretty is an undertaking in itself so it makes the grade for that.
Roguelike: 3 - As pure as they come, procedurally generated, turn-based, permadeath, (some) inventory management
Full Review: This game is a good demonstration that roguelikes don't have to be ugly and have controls that cause vi user's mouths to water. Unfortunately, it is more a tech demo than anything. It'd be interesting to see this game expanded into something along the lines of the Shiren the Wanderer.

Game: Dead Night Forest Chapter 2: The Lost Caravan
Completeness: 2 - Complete for a tech demo of 3d sword fighter.
Aesthetics: 1 - Played at 2560x1600, max graphics.  One must balance the detail of different texture layers or things are lop-sided.  Very hard to right-mouse on objects as they have a narrow active window.  Mouse is very sensitive.  Death screen is jarring and abrubt.  I do like the look of the characters & trees, and the nice lighting of campfires.
Fun: 1 - Was enjoyable for a bit, but it is too grinding to complete the first quest.  If there is more content, should be opened up sooner.  Combat is just kiting + button mashing it seems.
Innovation: 2 - This is an attempt at a FPS roguelike.  However, see roguelike comment.
Scope: 2 - Hard to tell without a better idea what comes packaged in unity.
Roguelike: 1 - BZ Flag isn't a roguelike.  Random levels are not enough.  You need tactical combat.  Space is not used in combat here, instead it is mostly about timing, making it very much a FPS and not at all a roguelike.
Full Review: Dead Night Forest is an attempt at a first-person roguelike.  You wander a dark forest punctuated by occasional campfires.  Those at the campfires you slay.  Unfortunately, it definitely feels like an FPS with random maps, not a roguelike viewed in the first person.

Completeness: 1 - Not really a complete game but rather a testing place for a combat system (although playable)
Aesthetics: 2 - Looks ok; UI could use some help like highlighting where your "Health" is... also nice would be an in-game explanation of what the game is about (had to lookup the website)
Fun: 2 - Fun if you want to discover the mechanics of the combat engine
Innovation: 2 - Card based combat has been tried before, but implementation is well-designed
Scope: 2 - Just adding a (interesting)combat mechanic to some randomly moving @ in the map
Roguelike: 3 - Is got most of the points in the book
Full Review: Played this via SSH, this entry seeks to test a somewhat complex combat engine based on "Tokens", worth a look.

Completeness: 3 - Complete with score tracking.
Aesthetics: 3 - It is so easy to get strange map technology wrong.  But this doesn't.  Movement is smooth.  The 8-way is intuitively mapped to the local cell choices.  The map scrolls *after* you move smoothly, giving smooth turn based motion.
Fun: 2 - Problem of this space may be it is just too big.  I feel my main strategy is just to run away.  No particular urge to clear one area.
Innovation: 3 - Not just interesting geometry, but some interesting enemies such as vines and worms designed around the Rook-like movement.
Scope: 2 - While I think there may be nothing more to add to the game, it definitely isn't a massive scoped game either.  It is very much the size it should be.
Roguelike: 3 - Tactical based dungeon crawler.
Full Review: Consider my mind blown.

Completeness: 2 - Plays, no crashes.  Pleanty of sharp corners, like how you start a new level with partial moves.
Aesthetics: 2 - It is a nice look with sound.  But putting important UI in the title bar meant it took me a longn time to figure out how many moves I had left.  Also thankfully I had been warned about hitting space before.  I like how everything orbits.
Fun: 1 - Blowing stuff up is fun, but the mechanic seems way too easy.
Innovation: 1 - Well outside of roguelike genre, so hard to say how it is innovative.
Scope: 1 - The @ on map equivalent of a strategy game.
Roguelike: 1 - The lack of exploration very much makes it a puzzle game, not a roguelike
Full Review: You are flying a space ship trying to destroy the evil space bases before they destroy you.  Fortunately for you, you have the SUN CRUSHER!! a weapon that can obliterate stores.  Unfortunately, it's blast radius is a bit big, so do be careful out there!

Completeness: 3 - Definitely a complete room with full beginning middle and end
Aesthetics: 3 - Light plays an important role in the game and the graphics handle this well, controls are simple and concentrated.
Fun: 3 - This is the first game so far this 7DRL that I will be playing again after this judging is complete. It his a compiling story the pulls you in enough to keep playing
Innovation: 2 - I don't think a single feature in this RL is completely original, but the light, one-hit kill, and death mechanics are weaved together better than many long running RLs.
Scope: 3 - Good story, good gameplay and decent balance at above and beyond in a 7DRL
Roguelike: 3 - A bit of a toss on this one, but it is procedurally generated, turn-based and has permadeath and limited inventory management
Full Review: This is probably one of the better psychological RLs I've seen in a 7DRL. The length makes it a coffee break game and it's as tight as they get. Could use some music, and maybe flickering lights or destructable lights (though the messages for when I tried knifing the lights was a nice touch). Overall, a solid title that is setting the bar high for horror themed RLs this year

Completeness: 1 - No victory condition, could only have properly refreshing FOV under Opera. Right clicks not captured properly.
Aesthetics: 2 - Fails to capture space which is also interpreted by browser. It should have been some other key to perform generic action.
Fun: 2 - Tougher enemies need to be handled carefully but due to overabundance of supplies it is hard to lose.
Innovation: 1 - Everything that could be called new was in Scrap years ago.
Scope: 2 - Some levels, interesting enemies.
Roguelike: 3 - Fits nicely.
Full Review: As a robot you may turn your power into ammunition, hit points or invisibility time. The point of Robo Captain is management of these resources.

Completeness: 1 - Bugs are too numerous to list.
Aesthetics: 1 - Menu based interface is broken in almost all respects. Three keystrokes to make an attack? Forget it.
Fun: 1 - This is a tech demo. Nothing playable.
Innovation: 1 - What innovation?
Scope: 1 - Declaring this a success is just wrong.
Roguelike: 3 - Okay, have to admit it fits.
Full Review: Not playable. Monsters are there but they die at random times and getting them to attack you or even move is really difficult. Essentially a failed 7DRL.

Completeness: 3 Didn't see any shortcomings
Aesthetics: 3 Basic ASCII with sensible keybindings and good visuals. Slight demerit for using 't' as both trees and creatures.
Fun: 2 Fun as it is, but rather simple
Innovation: 3 Several novel mechanics. There's puzzling out procedurally generated creatures, and a hot/cold game for finding the beacon.
Scope: 2 Just right for 7DRL, a small-scope game with some complex features competently implemented.
Roguelike: 3 It's a roguelike
Full Review: A planet exploration game with procedurally generated aliens, where your excuse for exploring the random planet is finding a hidden radio beacon that keeps your ship from lifting off. Figuring out the aliens, running away from them, and distracting them with appropriate treats is an interesting mechanic and nicely conveys a different tone than the usual slay-everything mode.

Completeness: 3 It does what it sets out to do
Aesthetics: 2 Basic interface is good and simple, and the light effects are good. There are text narration sequences that introduce a forced delay, which gets annoying fast. The prose is a bit overwritten, but just attempting a more narrativistic game is nice. For some reason no bump-to-attack.
Fun: 2 It's pretty straightforward and working, there's nothing dazzling in the mechanics. Couldn't figure out how to skip the cutscene I get when dying, stopped playing when I got it the third time.
Innovation: 3 Lots of good stuff, an original theme, a less crunchy, theme appropriate combat dynamic
Scope: 2 Seems around 7DRL level.
Roguelike: 3 It's a roguelike
Full Review: An atmospheric horror game that's set in a low-key abandoned basement full of unnaturally ferocious rats instead of the more usual monster-filled complex. Unskippable narrative cutscenes, for example every time you die, are a terrible UI decision, these NEED to be made skippable or the game is unplayable. Other than that, the thing shows definite promise, with the minimalist presentation showing a pretty convincing modern-day scenario.

Completeness: 1 Doesn't even appear to work.
Aesthetics: 1 Interface is broken
Fun: 1 Couldn't get fighting to work
Innovation: 1 A knight fights goblins.
Scope: 1 Not done
Roguelike: 2 I *think* it is, if it worked properly I could verify that. Proper roguelikes don't make you make 50 stat allocation decisions before you can start the game though.
Full Review: It starts by making me allocate 50 points, one by one, to stats. Don't do this, people. Nobody cares if the stat is 50 or 51, so don't make the player make the decision. The game itself is a buggy mess, couldn't make sense of combat or the actions.

Completeness: 3 - Feature complete, seems to balanced pretty well, only error I saw was the game over text overlapping
Aesthetics: 2 - The black and grey graphics are functional, though not a particularly big step up from ASCII. Controls are fairly clean, though buttons to click on to swap between character and inventory would have help. Music is a neat addition
Fun: 2 - Definitely a fun concept, but walking around hunting for crystals gets old eventually. Needs a bit more variety to the gameplay.
Innovation: 1 - "Dive to collect X items" seems to be a running theme this year. The gadgets and software concept is interesting, but nothing that hasn't been done before.
Scope: 2 - High for a two, but not quite a three. Plenty of content for a coffee break game though.
Roguelike: 3 - Features procedural levels and enemies, turn-based movement and permadeath. Definitely a full fledged RL
Full Review: A clean game, decent content and a fairly intuitive control scheme. Collect the crystals, upgrade you gear and shoot your way to the next level. The inventory system reminds me of the 30X9 series of games, but the control is definitely pure RL. The tiles are unique and retro, but some objects just look like soup. Music works well enough. Overall a solid title.

Completeness: 3 - Fully functional with a slick UI and even a useful title screen/intro. Did have a game once where no enemies showed up for a long time.. not sure if it was a bug and either way not worth knocking this to a 2.
Aesthetics: 3 - Controls very intuitive. Graphics are very cool and well beyond expectations for a 7drl, well done.
Fun: 3 - increasing shadow mechanic adds a hectic sense of fun to the game
Innovation: 2 - increasing shadow mechanic is a unique twist, something that should be explored further by roguelikes
Scope: 3 - Mind-boggling that it was done in 7 days
Roguelike: 3 - close to a 'pure' roguelike, especially the good parts, ignores lots of the bad
Full Review: Marooned on an alien planet, you must outrun the night (and its horrible shadow creatures) and find a way to repair your ship. The "night" is constantly encroaching from the side of the screen and pushes you forwards, adding a great hectic feel to the usual roguelike mechanics. Nice mix of weapons and usable items. UI was very sharp and polished, tiles equally so. Tile art was amazingly done, especially for a 7DRL.

Completeness: 2 - Was tempted to give 3 here but the game crashed on me once.
Aesthetics: 3 - Controls are so good I found reading the before playing a waste of time.
Fun: 2 - Challenging and inviting to replay but too short to make better impression.
Innovation: 2 - Darkness done in a special way.
Scope: 2 - Just one map but it works.
Roguelike: 3 - Conformant.
Full Review: One map where you need to find the key and reach the door on edge. Kill rats, spiders and snakes but flee from madman, haunt and the Grue! Manage your matches well until you can escape or get a lantern.

Completeness: 2 - No possibility to travel diagonally. Pirates can do this. Also the universe feels somewhat empty.
Aesthetics: 3 - The game is one huge win in this category.
Fun: 1 - Collecting stuff to convert into energy is boring. You need tons of energy to reach the center of galaxy.
Innovation: 2 - The beauty of procedurally generated world is matched only by previous Infiniverse.
Scope: 2 - Hard to measure.
Roguelike: 2 - Not enough combat to really be a roguelike.
Full Review: Guide a spaceship to the center of a galaxy. However, to fly you need a lot of energy. Collecting stuff to convert or selling stuff to buy hydrogen cheaply is plain boring. This might evolve into a great game in future.

Completeness: 3 - Very complete, although difficult
Aesthetics: 3 - Simplistic but pleasing. About as excellent as you could ask for ASCII.
Fun: 3 - Tactically pleasing gameplay.
Innovation: 2 - Nice continuity between dungeons. Special moves are a nice touch but a little hard to manage properly (e.g. cost in blood versus blood gained)
Scope: 2 - The perfect length/scope for a 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike
Full Review: You play as a magical sentient sword with a passion for violence. You "work" for King Viola, who is in a constant struggle with his mortal enemy, King Crimson. The quests you choose to undertake affect the outcome of their war. Quests invariably require dungeon diving, and using advanced sword techniques to crush enemies in tactically pleasing ways. Blood acts as both health and "power" to perform these advanced techniques, so there is a constant weighing of tactical options. Hate Kobolds. HATE.

Completeness: 2 - Seemingly complete as a game, but universe feels (too) empty.
Aesthetics: 3 - Very pleasing asthetics. +1 for browser games! UI is slick, scanning is fun. Movement could be a bit easier (shift+arrows did not seem to work for diagonals)
Fun: 1 - Not enough 'fun' gameplay. Combat is too dangerous, even after some upgrading. Mechanics have promise though, just need to remove micromanagement (esp. energy conversion).
Innovation: 2 - Universe generation and level of detail (down to planet surfaces!) is simply amazing. Would love to see it with more 'stuff'. Hard to compare to other roguelikes in these terms.
Scope: 2 - Scope seems huge, but so much emptiness can also be a bad thing. Features-wise scope is very wide, with buying/selling, tons of exploration.
Roguelike: 2 - Lacking in combat makes it tough to compare to other roguelikes but is certainly similar in other ways (exploration)
Full Review: You are a spaceship out to acquire knowledge and wealth. It has a great game Universe but without being a great game. Amazingly detailed universe, down to the planetary terrain. Problem is things are a bit TOO spread out and exploration becomes tedious very quickly, especially when coupled with energy-conversion mechanic. Not a lot of combat, and what combat there is is very difficult. However, graphics are amazing and 100% in-browser (+1 for me) and the UI is very slick (especially scanning/targeting). A great platform/framework for a new game.

Completeness: 3 - Feature complete and unintentional bug free
Aesthetics: 2 - Functional ASCII graphics and decent controls. Nothing that blew me out of the water, but it works well for the game.
Fun: 2 - Fun enough for a coffe break. Probably one of the better made meta-RLs I've played. Also, still the developer choose to make emacs more powerful than vi, it's fun to think of the holy war he is inviting.
Innovation: 2 - Meta RLs aren't too common and I like the hard trade off mechanic (all potions increase one stat and derease another)
Scope: 2 - Pretty much right on par for a 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - Despite the quirky subject matter, this game is pure RL. Procedural maps, permadeath, turn-based and inventory management.
Full Review: An intresting game where you player a coder coding a 7DRL. Self referenial has been done before, TheChallenge carves out its own niche. It is a solid coffee break title that is sure to make any 7DRL developer crack a smile or shed a tear, either or.

Completeness: 2 - Stable, but lacks content to be considered complete
Aesthetics: 3 - Nice looking, very accesible
Fun: 1 - Too short and simple
Innovation: 1 - It has powers you can only use depending on your current hitpoints
Scope: 2 - Monster on the map with 3 skills and spawning enemies. Gets bonus for the graphics.
Roguelike: 1 - Turn based puzzle.
Full Review: You are a cute monster rampaging through a set of islands, bashing their puny defenses with your might. This is a pretty short turn based puzzle game with nice graphics and limited ways of interaction.

Completeness: 1 - Has some critical bugs and feels unpolished (I was unable to use the remote view for example)
Aesthetics: 2 - Standard ASCII look, commands a bit obscure
Fun: 1 - Baring the fact of frequent crashes, there's the premise of a mission based game, but I was unable to get to a point where interesting missions showed up.
Innovation: 2 - Conveyor belts, remote view (though I was unable to see it working) Combining things didnt really seem to work that well (was unable to know what I was combining, always got weaponized toys no matter). Running spends your stamina which doubles as your health
Scope: 2 - He aimed for a nice goal.
Roguelike: 3 - Turn based, inventory, postmortem.
Full Review: Not very complete, has some interesting features (see innovation) yet not a fun game.

Completeness: 1 - Seems like a really rushed "success", there's not enough meat here to make a playable, fun and accessible experience
Aesthetics: 1 - Really rough, with full screen refreshes, black and white and unintuitive inventory management.
Fun: 1 - It's a survival game with one hit deaths, so the only fun you'll get is trying to survive long enough without losing your patience or running into a dead-end
Innovation: 1 - Nothing new here, survive against infinite waves of enemies with your single bump attack and no weapons or skill for as long as I tried
Scope: 1 - A very basic running world
Roguelike: 1 - A survival game with some tactical combat situations, very slight procedural generation (a bit irrelevant because you are stuck in the middle of a swamp and cant move much). No variety at all in enemies and items or interactions. Sorry :)
Full Review: Survive waves of evil monsters while you stand in the middle of a swamp. Both the monsters and you die with a single hit so be careful. Not a finished game nor anywhere near. I find very little to rescue here.

Completeness: 2 The game is there, but it hasn't been tested. Building from source is broken on Linux, and the game seems inadequate in telling you what to do
Aesthetics: 2 The basic height-varying map mechanic works nicely. Not cluttered with unnecessary commands, but the commands there are aren't very discoverable without reading the readme.
Fun: 2 It does have nice bits with the survival angle (you're as likely as not to be chasing down edible critters as facing foes in combat) and the terrain. On the other hand, seems incomplete and does basically nothing to clue you in on what you should be trying to accomplish.
Innovation: 3 A well-implemented heightmapped terrain system that works both visually and mechanically, and an unusual, but setting-appropriate gameplay for the not that often seen SF setting. Looks promising.
Scope: 2 The heightmapped survival game is pretty well in 7DRL scope
Roguelike: 3 I think the map is fixed, though probably still procedurally generated, so that should be just a matter of seeding the RNG. Otherwise, turn-based single-mode single-character resource management avatar game with permadeath.
Full Review: A game based on the Dune novels. Building from source on Linux didn't even start to work, until the cabal did some makefile doctoring and emergency bugfixing. (It's easy enough to test linux stuff with a live-CD folks.) Game itself has a nice premise. You're Duke Leto Atreides, and you need to find your way back to your house base from being stranded on Dune. Only problem with this is that there's a lot of directions the house base could be in in the wide open 2D desert, and you don't seem to have any idea which way to go. Fortunately, folk at House Atreides don't seem to balk at killing and eating other humans for the delicious hydration in their bodies. There are even some Atreides countrymen wandering around the desert, and there seems to be nothing to do with them other than kill them and eat their corpses. That's useful enough, but I would have liked some directions towards the base as well.

Completeness: 3 - Seems feature complete, balance is pretty good, all the enemies have unique flavor texts.
Aesthetics: 2 - Functional Ascii graphics, the controls are a little nethacky, but functional.
Fun: 2 - Fun but a bit frustrating as death happens quickly and recovery items are rare in the early game. Would be nice to see some of mid-game features pull forward a bit.
Innovation: 1 - Nothing particularly new, using a Warhammer skin is neat though
Scope: 2 - On par for a 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - All the standard RL features are present, procedural generation, permadeath, inventory management, allies and turn-based movement
Full Review: This game feels a bit like a Warhammer themed brogue variant. It plays well and has a decent amount of content for a 7DRL. Combat is pretty lethal early on and managing allies can be a bit fiddling and time consuming. I'd be interesting to see this game expanded in the ally combat dimension, where you could have dozens of orks under your control.

Completeness: 1 - More of a tech demo (or 'toy' in the author's words) than a game
Aesthetics: 2 - Hand-drawn art is a nice look. Always moving the targeting reticle is annoying.. defaulting to the nearest enemy would be an easy fix.
Fun: 1 - Good to see something on Android but not really a game.
Innovation: 1 - Not really enough gameplay content to judge this category. +0.5 for being on Android, but this counts as technical innovation and not gameplay innovation.
Scope: 1 - Excellent effort for a new platform, but not enough here to justify a 2. Would love to see more. Android seems to have an obvious roguelike hole to fill.
Roguelike: 2 - Would give this a 3 but not enough gameplay to truely determine roguelikeness. However, what is there is clearly a roguelike, so far.
Full Review: Android has an obvious roguelike hole to fill, but this game is not ready to fill it yet. An excellent proof of concept that such games can (and SHOULD) be made, though! The hand-drawn look is very unique and especially easy on the eyes. But in the authors own words, this was more of a toy than a game. More please!

Completeness: 3 - Fully complete. Polished. Nice use of libtcod without going overboard.
Aesthetics: 2 - Pleasing to look at. Looks like a libtcod roguelike, but not over-done. Nice lighting effects on mage/priest spell attacks, and dragon-fire. Could use slightly more varied terrain, even just slightly different/varying colors for walls. I dig the re-use of archetypical nethack/rogue character codes (e.g. D, @).
Fun: 3 - Good solid fun. Recommended to all roguelike fans. Some built-in humor playing as a 'D'ragon when the @-signs show up.
Innovation: 2 - Nothing crazy in terms of new roguelike gameplay elements, but excellent integration of abilities w/ cooldowns. Reversal of theme is innovative as well.
Scope: 3 - Would've given a 2 until I got to explore the entire depth of the ability tree. Very well done without being overwhelming. Shades of borderlands (in a good way).
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike.
Full Review: Play as a dragon growing from a young wyrmling to powerful Great Wyrm. Surprisingly deep abilities tree makes every new level fun and often tactically different. Corpses as a combination of health & level completeness is also a very interesting mechanic that is done very well, and should be explored further. Enemies surprisingly varied with well-animated magical attacks, class abilities (rogues will disappear and pop out to stab you), and even some humor ('the Paladin judges you'). Occasional 'arena' levels are a challenge, especially in the late game, terrain could use some more color but what do you expect from a lava chasm? Breathing fire and biting entire enemies is very satisfying and brings across the feeling of being a dragon very well.

Completeness: 3 - Pretty polished and stable, nice amounts of content
Aesthetics: 3 - Nice choice of colors and UI design. Keybindings sensible
Fun: 2 - Turn battles can get a bit tedious, but interesting skills spice them up. Maps are big and dull. Corridor battles are very unfun
Innovation: 2 - Team tactics on a roguelike is tried from time to time. This one is item-less, with a simplified recruiting system and focuses on gaining skills.
Scope: 2 - Went all the way for the tactics combat, neglecting a more interesting environment generation
Roguelike: 3 - Is got most of the High Valued Components plus a strong "monsters are players"
Full Review: Dungeon diving recruiting enemies on the way and fighting turn based battles ala final fantasy tactics. Pretty polished and with a decent amount of monsters and skills. Maps are a bit huge and dull.

Completeness: 2 - Missing a great deal of polish, development continued post 7DRL
Aesthetics: 2 - Keybindings are simple and clear. Not very pleasing to the eye
Fun: 1 - Too easy once you get the hang of it, no challenge
Innovation: 2 - Your body grows as you eat enemies. All enemies move according to a pattern
Scope: 1 - Got some mobs running on a single screen and the player eating them with single hits
Roguelike: 1 - More of a puzzle game
Full Review: You are a wyrm moving around a single screen eating all enemies before they kill you. You keep growing as you kill enemies not unlike a cellphone snake.

Completeness: 3 - Seems feature complete and balanced
Aesthetics: 2 - Controls smoothly, nice graphics, though they are a bit cut and paste-y
Fun: 1 - The game is basically a puzzle shooter, it's not bad in its current incarnation, but it's pretty repeative. It definitely could use some variablity.
Innovation: 1 - Nothing too unique about a turn based puzzle shooter. More variablity would help.
Scope: 2 - Seems about right for a 7DRL entry
Roguelike: 1 - Definitely a puzzle game with random layouts
Full Review: You move a ship around with a number of turns and take potshots at enemy ships that shoot back and consume your shields. Not a bad game in its current form, but not really a roguelike and it could definitely use some more content.

Completeness: 2 - No glaring bugs, but lacking polish. Movement is awkward, balance seems to need some work.
Aesthetics: 1 - I'm not a fan of the reflex meter, it eliminates all of the "plan and move" aspects of a roguelike. That might wore in a full real-time RL, but in a semi-RT RL it is just odd. Graphics are functional, but controls need work, but that's more of TOME's fault than this games.
Fun: 1 - Currently, this game is just frustrating to play. Cleaning up the controls a bit and reworking the reflex timer would help a lot.
Innovation: 3 - Hex based, semi-real time, significant social aspects, the developer aimed high, but bit off a bit more than he could chew.
Scope: 2 - Big aspirations turned into a fairly average success as far as implemented features goes.
Roguelike: 2 - No significant procedurally generation that I could see, but most of the other RL traits are present.
Full Review: Probably the game that aimed highest that I've play so far this cycle. You go into the arena and get your ass handed to you unless you mash the 1/2 keys like mad and pray that your enemy is distracted. The developer introduce real time elements that reward you for acting quickly, but mostly they punish you for not button mashing. A good start for a game, with some polishing this might turn out to be a gem.

Completeness: 3 A full playable game with complete features and mechanics
Aesthetics: 3 Functional graphics and an efficient control scheme without extra bits. The combo interface is particularly nice.
Fun: 3 Much fun, the basic mechanic is interesting and graspable very quickly. Don't know how far it would go, but definitely works in a coffeebreak game scope.
Innovation: 2 A unique single-hitpoint PC mechanic, though beyond that it's just beating up demons.
Scope: 2 Spot on for 7drl.
Roguelike: 3 It's a roguelike. With a bit squishier player character than usual.
Full Review: The gimmick here is that you need to fight a bunch of demons with some superpowers, but are a regular squishy human (or equivalent) otherwise, and can't take even a single hit without dying. Good thing the demons freeze for a bit when you punch them. So you can fight single opponents easily, but if you get surrounded, you can't freeze-juggle everyone and are dead. You can move around the arena rooms and use strike combos to get by. The combo interface is neat, you use the directional keys to choose a context-appropriate combo move.

Completeness: 2 Great basic procedural universe, but there's not much goal for the player.
Aesthetics: 3 Excellent realization of the procedural universe, both visually and functionally. Key bindings work well, with a smooth navigation from galactic level to planetary surface.
Fun: 2 Exploring planets is visually nice, but there's not much to actually do.
Innovation: 2 Quite different for roguelikes, but doesn't do much Starflight didn't already do 25 years ago.
Scope: 3 Implementing the entire galaxy is, well, perhaps a bit over the scope for 7DRL.
Roguelike: 2 The basic feel is there, but the wild scale shifts are rather un-roguelike, and there's not that much indication yet how tactical gameplay would work into these.
Full Review: A procedural space exploration game, with really excellent visuals and controls, but also succumbing to the perennial problem of procedural space exploration games that there's not that much to do beyond looking at the pretty simplex noise planets, and given that there's a whole galaxy to play with, it might not be that easy to come up with meaningful gameplay involving all of it either.

Completeness: 3 Complete game
Aesthetics: 3 Very stylish retro-8-bit graphics and sound. Interface is very intuitive.
Fun: 3 Lots of fun, straightforward tactical gameplay with lots of pattern learning opportunities.
Innovation: 2 Great aesthetic for a coffeebreak game, and doesn't devolve into cliches, but nothing really ground-breaking either.
Scope: 2 Just right for a 7DRL
Roguelike: 3 It looks unconventional, but definitely roguelike.
Full Review: An infinite dive game with the look and feel of a slightly surreal 8-bit game. Combat is deterministic, and the enemies have rigid movement patterns. There's an identification game combined with pattern prediction, and you're basically just trying to get through each room alive.

Completeness: 3 Seems pretty full-featured
Aesthetics: 2 Visuals ok, but the interface is a bit clumsy. Healing wounds seems unnecessarily involved.
Fun: 2 Didn't quite figure this out yet, the traditional RL surprise traps don't lend themselves to a very interesting gameplay, though the animated blades and such were new.
Innovation: 2 Making a game entirely around surviving traps is an interesting concept, and there are some neat turn-based animated traps that you need to synchronize with that haven't been seen much in RLs.
Scope: 2 Just right for a 7DRL
Roguelike: 3 It's a roguelike.
Full Review: A game set entirely around surviving a complex full of traps. An interesting concept, but I didn't quite figure out how it's supposed to work, as a lot of the traps were still of the boring staple of "Surprise! Have 2d6 points of damage!" sort, and it's not really obvious what the interesting player decisions that would lead to avoiding those are. Also seems somewhat buggy, on the first playthrough the pusher tiles in front of the complex entrance appeared in a configuration that never let me enter.

Completeness: 2 - Throwing flasks gives internal error. Having armor/weapon break or changing body armor causes "gaining resistance" debug message to be output.
Aesthetics: 3 - Good choice of colors although items on ground could use some distinction. Keys very neat. Actions display only eligible items.
Fun: 3 - Martin's Dungeon Bash was fun thing and so is this. However, lava walking has swung balance a little too much in player's favor.
Innovation: 1 - The only rare thing to see is lava walking but it has been done too.
Scope: 1 - Cave chop was a backup plan anyway. Changes from MPRDB are minimal.
Roguelike: 3 - 100% roguelikeness.
Full Review: Essentially a mod of Martin's Dungeon Bash. New things include cave area instead of a maze of rooms, unusable flasks and some new items. If you liked MPRDB Cave Chop is fun too.

Completeness: 2 - Ladders seem to not always be generated making the game unwinnable.
Aesthetics: 3 - Nice looking tiles and animated monsters. Keys sensible for most part and good help screen.
Fun: 2 - Lots of interesting things to do but inability to win prevents me from rating it higher.
Innovation: 1 - All stuff is standard.
Scope: 3 - There are so many things to do it is almost unbelieveable to be done in seven days.
Roguelike: 3 - Yes.
Full Review: Standard hack and slash in modern era. There are only two types of monsters to fight but repertoire of items is very large. Overall quite fun game.

Completeness: 1 - Rarely crashes with critical error. There are numerous cases when player is exposed to IDENTIFIERS_LOOKING_LIKE_THIS_ONE.
Aesthetics: 2 - No idea why one needs to switch action assigned to Z and X. Kebindings seem to be made without reason.
Fun: 1 - Lack of a goal or a sense of progress makes playing this a dull experience.
Innovation: 3 - Shifting between worlds is something totally new and has been nicely fleshed out.
Scope: 2 - A lot of art was prepared but everything else suffered.
Roguelike: 2 - Lacks many roguelike elements.
Full Review: Strange game. You play several characters and switch control between them every once a while. There might be a goal or a message in the game but I did not bear the dull gameplay for long enough to get it.

Completeness: 1 - Lua errors on every corner, victory condition improperly implemented. House names disagree in few places.
Aesthetics: 2 - Picking up a weapon is a talent! Who would guess.
Fun: 2 - Battle outcome depends much more on character skill and stats than on moves taken by player.
Innovation: 2 - Skipping a turn to increase chances of hitting temporarily is not something one sees often.
Scope: 2 - About right for a 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - One on one combat is uncommon but fully roguelike.
Full Review: As a gladiator you will fight two types of matches. Grudge is standard duel. Discovery is about killing your opponent or breaking jars to find a hidden gem in one of them. A jar might also contain a weapon or angry creature that will fight you. Winning several matches earns you freedom.

Completeness: 3 - Wrong indefinite article for picking up emacs.
Aesthetics: 3 - Looks fine but could use a few more colors here and there. Keys easy to master.
Fun: 3 - I am biased but I found this simple hack and slash very fun because of theme.
Innovation: 1 - Only the theme is unique.
Scope: 2 - This begs for extension.
Roguelike: 3 - No doubt.
Full Review: What kind of programmer has the best chances to complete 7DRL Challenge? According to this game he is outrageously lazy, furiously impatient and full of hubris. Fix bugs, segmentation faults, memory leaks and take care of exceptions. Be very wary of family affairs. Oh, the idea that emacs is better editor than vi is HERESY!!! You hear me?! HERESY!

Completeness: 1 - Occassional random assertion failure, locks up after death. Sight artifacts. Does not tell you 'talk to whom' has to be answered by mouse click.
Aesthetics: 2 - Keys well chosen and great looks but no help screen. I had to read the source for keybindings.
Fun: 3 - There are three distinct playstyles and all works really well.
Innovation: 3 - Guards whom you have convinced of your innocence help you fast talk other guards. Similarly, hostile guards attempt to thwart you attempts at pacifyin others.
Scope: 2 - Could use more balancing and better user interface.
Roguelike: 3 - Yeah.
Full Review: Somewhere on a map is an item to pick up. Find it and get back to starting point. You have to deal with guards somehow By force, by stealth or by fast talking your way through. Usually a combination of all three is most successful.

Completeness: 1 Lacks some polishing. The message log can overflow the game window. It took me a while to understand that you cannot actually move inside a room, just teleport from one room to another. Some times I get a blank screen after a move.
Aesthetics: 1 huge characters with flashy and primary colors
Fun: 1 I've been really annoyed by the weird interface, game rules and even the creatures names (a cat-dog and a cthulu?)
Innovation: 2 really tries to bring some new feats, but for me they really don't work
Scope: 1 basically, there's map generation and click to attack
Roguelike: 3 despite some really strange feats, it's a true roguelike
Full Review: a very basic roguelike with an awkward interface and a strange requirement to log with a google account. Weird game mechanisms too. For example, you're tired as soon as you hit a creature once. Also the map seems non-euclidean. For example you can go from room 1 to room 2 going north. Then going west from room 2 brings you back in room 1.

Completeness: 3 no special issue playing the game through ssh
Aesthetics: 2 effort has been made to avoid the default palette. uses standard roguelike keys
Fun: 2 classic dungeon dweller with attack on bump and some innovative powerup system
Innovation: 2 grabbing powerups making it possible to alter yourself. Also playing as a golem is new
Scope: 2 good ideas but require more work
Roguelike: 3 classic roguelike
Full Review: A classic roguelike you can play in a terminal. There are the bases of an interesting powerup system where alter yourself by using powerups dropped by enemies, but it's still at the very early stage

Completeness: 2 - Great job of reutilizing the already mighty EUO engine, didn't have the time to polish some rough edges and thus make a complete transformation. Game-wise you can play a complete game here
Aesthetics: 2 - Excellent old school look, somewhat complex old school keybindings :) Music gets annoying after a while.
Fun: 3 - Classic roguelike fun, very much worth your time to play!
Innovation: 2 - Rage bar
Scope: 3 - A whole game reutilizing an existing engine
Roguelike: 3 - A great example of shaping a roguelike from a non-roguelike engine
Full Review: Well, you should check out EUO if you don't know it. This game was derived from the EUO engine, changed to fit the theme and the gameplay mechanics while keeping its solidity and eye candy. Protip: Use 'M' to turn off the music, it's funny but gets annoying after a time. There are 3 races and 3 classes, each one with unique features.

Completeness: 3 - Very impressive piece of software, an infinite universe in which you can zoom in an out from galaxies to planets with randomly generated landscape, all running in your web browser. Also a target based ranged combat system.
Aesthetics: 3 - Great unicode look powered by colors, in-game help takes you along. Keyset is small and comprehensive
Fun: 1 - Not much to do apart from roaming the universe looking for things to sell and then hoping to reach a space station.
Innovation: 1 - I am sure this has been tried before (although this execution is excellent). Plus it's not very roguelike
Scope: 3 - He created an universe albeit a bit empty
Roguelike: 1 - Not a roguelike but rather a turn based single played space trading game. Has randomly generated maps and limited tactical combat tho.
Full Review: This one lets you have an universe in your browser, very elegant implementation and may be the basis for a great game with multiple facets apart from trading. Right now there's a game here you might want to master, but it's all about patience and luck.

Completeness: 2 - It is well polished but getting this to run was a major pain.
Aesthetics: 3 - Controls for dealing with module installation are awkward but good looks and weapon animations make up for it.
Fun: 2 - Not enough feedback in combat. I am rarely not sure whether a robot was hit and if yes did it receive damage. It is a bit hard to guess what kind of damage weapons do.
Innovation: 3 - It follows in the steps of Scrap but takes it much further. Multiple systems of one type can be effectively used.
Scope: 3 - There is great amount of modules to try swapping in and out. Design well thought out.
Roguelike: 3 - Fully roguelike.
Full Review: If you played Scrap the game will look very familiar. You are robot with ability to replace your own parts. This is very interesting mix and match. However, your modules can be destroyed and often are. A downside is battles tend to take too long because of long streaks of misses and uninterruptible animations.

Completeness: 1 - Very basic engine setup with little playability
Aesthetics: 2 - Looks nice. User interaction model is pretty confusing
Fun: 1 - Unbalanced combat, about 5 rooms to  "Explore", no character advancement
Innovation: 1 - Room based movement has been explored. Web deployment has been done as well.
Scope: 1 - Walk on the map (room based), no procedural generation, no variety.
Roguelike: 1 - More like a Telengard-like (at least aiming to be)
Full Review: An experiment on a room based web deployed game. Requires a lot more of development to become playable. You can give it a try online, click the exits or the enemies to attack

Completeness: 2 - Very polished look and feel, missing enough depth of gameplay to warrant a 3.
Aesthetics: 3 - A pleasure to look at and control. The way the screen jumps to follow the @ is amazing.
Fun: 2 - Totally fun to play and look at (even if you aren't playing), but missing enough content to make it a full replayable game.
Innovation: 3 - Have rarely seen a hex map done as well as this. Parabolic world is also very innovative and worth exploration by other games.
Scope: 2 - About what I'd expect from a 7drl. A unique concept executed tightly and with decent polish.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike.
Full Review: A unique experimental roguelike with lots of potential. Visuals are very hard to describe and definitely worth checking out! Player travels through a parabolic world on a hex map that is constantly curving away from the player in all directions. Player must avoid obstacles and destroy enemies without getting stuck -- the game has a nice 'check mate' feature that will prevent you from making ill-fated moves. Not a ton of depth but visually very impressive.

Completeness: 3 - Small, complete game
Aesthetics: 2 - Nice looking and easy to play, gets really messed up when you are insane (messages get their letters scrambled), would have been nicer to show insanity in some other, less annoying way :) Also has some ambient "terror" sounds but I am inmune to that so I don't know how well it works
Fun: 2 - There's a game here
Innovation: 2 - Some enemies damage your insanity instead of health, being in the dark also makes you go nuts
Scope: 2 - About what I'd expect from a 7drl. A unique concept executed tightly and with decent polish.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike.
Full Review: A small game about you escaping a terror house without losing your mind. Nice done although a bit shallow. Has plans for extending it in the future.

Completeness: 3 - Works very smoothly. Looks very polished.
Aesthetics: 2 - Looks very nice, very JRPG-type graphics. However, -1 for combat controls, having to 'pass' each turn when you have run out of actions becomes very tedious.
Fun: 2 - Will not be everyone's cup of tea but has a seemingly deep combat game/RPG going on.
Innovation: 1 - Hard to tell for this game. In order to innovate, there needs to a 'base' "roguelike-ishness" to start from and innovate on, which this game does not have. (unless you count perma-death)
Scope: 3 - Graphics/text/polish in the title sequence(s) alone seem more than is possible for a 7DRL, well done.
Roguelike: 1 - Definitely not a roguelike. (Unless you count permadeath, but in which case make the characters way easier/shorter to set up please!)
Full Review: A very polished-looking JRPG-type game with interesting tactical combat. Not really a roguelike except for permadeath, which is not really enough to count! Will likely find plenty of fans among lovers of the genre. Certainly has enough polish to make a roguelike in the same setting/engine potentially interesting.

Completeness: 1 - Basic engine running, missing critical features
Aesthetics: 2 - Nothing exciting on the display side of things, side views for x and y are nice but since they aren't adding to gameplay they are just taking over a huge chunk of screen. Keys are pretty simple and straightforward
Fun: 1 - Right now there's no challenge thus no fun experience, you can run around forever shooting myriads of torpedoes and nothing will stop you
Innovation: 1 - Depth. Also, not many submarine roguelikes out there. But fails to use depth as a gameplay element so...
Scope: 2 - If only it had been more complete it would have been a standard 7DRL scope
Roguelike: 1 - Not a roguelike, irrelevant terrain generation (if any), lack of tactical combat, no items/powerups/skills. More of a puzzle game in its current shape
Full Review: You are a submarine deployed on the sea, you have to destroy ships by launching torpedoes at them. You can five into the sea and climb back (but it's not very useful). Ships dont seek or attack you so there's little danger. More of a tech demo right now

Completeness: 2 - Runs and is seemingly stable. No polish.
Aesthetics: 1 - Extremely frustrating to start.. would not run without going through the entire title sequence, which slowly shows the title of the game over the course of ~90 seconds, and is (apparently?) unskippable. Colors are monochrome, which is not a negative mark. Controls seem solid and do what you'd expect, once you get to the game!
Fun: 1 - I did not have any fun playing this one, sadly. (died in my first combat every time, after waiting through the entire start screen)
Innovation: 1 - Seemingly standard hack+slash combat.
Scope: 2 - Hard to judge because it is so difficult to get beyond 1 enemy, but has the benefit of the doubt due to the seeming depth of the item/weapon/equipment
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike
Full Review: A hard core (read: impossible) monochromatic hack and slash roguelike. Extremely difficult so hard to judge how deep the gameplay gets. Intro screen takes way way way way too long and is apparently unskippable. Lack of any in-game or out-of-game help.

Completeness: 2 - Stable, runs in unity. Lacks a bit of polish.
Aesthetics: 2 - With 3D it is easy for things to get obnoxious very quick but this game does a good job of presenting the dungeon and units. Controls do what you'd expect.
Fun: 2- A very interesting concept. The stop/start nature of enemy movement (game time only moves when you move) is worth exploration. Leading a pack of enemies over a series of spikes is very gratifying.
Innovation: 3 - A neat twist on the usual mechanics. Semi-real-time game click only ticks forward when the player moves or attacks. Real-time movement also allows for momentum-based attacks, which is fun.
Scope: 2 - A solid 7DRL.
Roguelike: 2 - Semi-real-time so not a "pure" roguelike in my book but certainly a roguelike-like! (Note that this is not a bad thing, hence the increased innovation score)
Full Review: A fun little 3D dungeon-slasher done in Unity. Game runs in semi-real-time, so enemies only move when the player moves or attacks, which can lead to some interesting tactics and some tricky situations. Not a ton of depth here, game-wise, but the core mechanic is fun and worth checking out. (Also the momentum-based attacks are lots of fun)

Completeness: 3 - Super-polished. Title sequence alone makes most games look like a pile of garbage.
Aesthetics: 3 - Lots of elegantly-done blood violence is very nice to look at. Very pleasing to play, controls are not 100% what I'd expect (space to rest) but there is in-game help.
Fun: 3 - Lots of fun to wail on bad guys. 1 HP mechanic makes you really consider every tiny move on a tactical level. (This is a good thing)
Innovation: 2 - Was not able to explore the 'powers' in a lot of detail but the game does do some interesting things well in terms of forcing the player into making tactical decisions at almost every turn.
Scope: 2 - A solid 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike.
Full Review: A very nice-looking game that forces the player to make hard tactical decisions at almost every turn (due to the fact that you only have 1 HP). Intro sequence alone makes the game worth playing. Was not able to explore the powers... game is very difficult even in the first few fights.

Completeness: 1 - Misses many critical features, enemies don't move and are not removed from the map when they die. They also die mysteriously.
Aesthetics: 2 - Nice looking, keybindings take a little to get used to but are ok.
Fun: 1 - Not yet, enemies just stand there and you've got nothing to do but roam the empty forest.
Innovation: 1 - Nothing new
Scope: 2 - Instead of going for an enjoyable game, the dev went for the foundations of an engine.
Roguelike: 3 - I guess enemies where supposed to chase you around. It's got random terrain and an inventory system among some other roguelike elements
Full Review: Not much of a game currently, the dev seems to have made the foundations for a roguelike engine during those 7 days. Enemies don't move and there are no cool features. Good luck to the dev with future developments.

Completeness: 2 Pretty good, but lacks a bit polish in vital stuff like moving the PC.
Aesthetics: 3 Makes good use of the Oryx tiles, mouse interface. Look is polished. Feels a bit like a turn-based Diablo or Realm of the Mad God.
Fun: 2 The look is neat, but gameplay is a bit samey shooting of the unusually ranged-combat-capable birds and snakes.
Innovation: 1 Pretty standard dungeon crawl.
Scope: 2 Pretty much in 7DRL scope, though effort seems more focused on visual style than novel gameplay.
Roguelike: 3 It's a roguelike
Full Review: A mouse-controlled graphical game, where your main attack is shooting at things. The basis looks nice, and the control gives it a Diablo-like feel. Unfortunately there's no way to do continuous walking, either by leaning on keys or by keeping the mouse button pressed. This makes moving around the large dungeon unnecessarily clumsy, and since avatar movement is a pretty big deal in roguelikes, this is currently a problem. Would be pretty easy to fix though.

Completeness: 3 It seems to be doing what it tries to do.
Aesthetics: 2 The interface is pretty simple, but not really like either a roguelike or a Jagged Alliance game. The menu graphics are good, but the levels are very, very plain.
Fun: 2 There's a basic game there, but the controls seem a bit too simplistic. Squad game maneuvers like popping in a doorway to shoot into a room and going back into cover are hard to pull off without getting shot. The game experience feels like a very simple real-time strategy game more than a roguelike.
Innovation: 2 It's trying to do squad-based, which is always interesting.
Scope: 2 It goes for a bunch of stuff but mostly sticks to the straightforward single missions.
Roguelike: 2 Not quite there. The world model is roguelike, but the gameplay feel when you give indirect orders to multiple characters is quite different.
Full Review: A game based on the Jagged Alliance games, but one that doesn't really play like either a roguelike or a JA game, but instead resembles a real-time strategy game. You give the characters orders like a place to travel to, and they do their own stuff until finished, at which point you get back to giving them orders. Didn't really get a good command flow going with this, guiding the guys felt clumsy both when moving the squads around (can't rect-select multiple guys) and in close combat, where the system was too simplistic for the JA style maneuvers like going prone or doing shoot-and-run moves.

Completeness: 3 - The only problem is monsters spawning near stairs which may cause an instakill. Otherwise very polished. Very instructive readme file.
Aesthetics: 3 - Controls are old good NetHack style. Commands using weapon slots are cleverly done. Bland looks though.
Fun: 3 - Clear rules make picking the dream set of weapons a tough choice. Each combat is fun puzzle of finding a weakness and exploiting it. Polymorph is neat too. Every death teaches something.
Innovation: 3 - There are some very clever mechanics. Weapon power varies due to numerous factors. Crystal spear is most useful in tight corridors while boomerang in open spaces. There are many more.
Scope: 3 - Nine levels, a bunch of weapons and monsters with varying qualities. Three level generation algorithms. Each promotes different weapons and requires alteration of tactics. Most surprisingly all the mess is well balanced.
Roguelike: 3 - Roguelike all the way.
Full Review: Sword testing is a dangerous job. The goal is to find good weapon to off an Ancient Dragon. What if you do not find such a weapon? Prepare to become the reptile's another meal. You can check what properties a given weapon has and need to decide whether you want to carry it further. Monsters have their own abilities too. If you desire one very much you can polymorph into a creature after defeating it. To be successful you should read readme file and carefully think about interaction of rules. After you get it the game becomes almost too easy.

Completeness: 3 - Large world, no bugs encountered.
Aesthetics: 3 - Despite seven directions it is easy to navigate. Stunningly beautiful.
Fun: 3 - I had great fun exploring this world. Every area has something interesting to it.
Innovation: 3 - For the topology alone. There are other twists in Hyperbolic Rogue.
Scope: 2 - About right because it builds up on previous version.
Roguelike: 3 - There are temporary buff instead of items. No other strays from roguelikeness.
Full Review: Play this thing. So awesome ... I recommend to visit the Alchemist Lab with its two color rules, Desert with sand worms and spice, raid shifting Living Caves for gold, see the Jungle and battle Ivy ... Just go anywhere and you likely will have fun.

Completeness: 2 - Polished but could really use more features.
Aesthetics: 3 - Minimal controls and nice tiles.
Fun: 2 - I crush teh buildings! RAWR!
Innovation: 2 - Okay, I do not reacall any working roguelike about being giant monster wrecking cities.
Scope: 1 - Not much really.
Roguelike: 1 - Lacks most of profoundly roguelike features.
Full Review: Play a giant monster stomps on buildings. Underneath there may be a tank producing factory. As the city is approaching complete destruction more and more tanks chase you. Fun but short.

Completeness: 3 - Polished, feature completed, balanced enough that I didn't win on my first try, but I did by the end of my lunch break.
Aesthetics: 3 - Very nice tile graphics, controls look complicated, but all you really use are 1-8 and the f and g keys.
Fun: 3 - Running like a madman from the shadow while trying to kill enough get power spheres and power ups is quite fun. Will probably pick this one up after the 7DRL is complete and watch for updates
Innovation: 2 - Nothing amazingly new, but an innovative little story and the optional real-time shadow is nice. Would have been nice to see more down with the shadow mechanics.
Scope: 2 - A high 2, largely because the graphics are nice, but this is on the high end of what I expect from 7DRLs.
Roguelike: 3 - A low 3, it has procedural generation, permadeath and turn-based mechanics, but the moving shadow and pure-powerups are a bit un-roguelike. Still a 3 though.
Full Review: A fun game where you dash to the right to escape an ever advancing shadow. The normal mode has the shadow moving each turn and the hardmode has it advance in real time. Overall an awesome coffee break RL. The gameplay is tight and well balanced, the graphics are stellar and story is decent. Only problems I encountered are a modest lack of documentation (weapons and armor, etc), a bug where monsters aren't respawned in a new game, and some of the items really aren't too useful, particularly the mine.

Completeness: 2 - Stable, but could use a bit of polish to make it a 3.
Aesthetics: 2 - Monochromatic color scheme, but works well for the setting. Ambient background music is used very well. Could've used a better way to swap between inventory and char screen (i and c are very far apart!). Mouse-only input is handled well, although pathfinding as opposed to single-space-per-click would be an obvious improvement.
Fun: 3 - It's fun! Takes a bit of time to get to the tough decisions, but once you figure out how to manage energy flow vs. energy consumption, there are some fun tactical choices multiple times per level.
Innovation: 2 - Power-management subgame makes this different from other roguelikes. Oxygen does not feel forced or tacked-on like some 'food clocks'. Other systems (energy, armor) handled very well.
Scope: 2 - A strong showing for a 7DRL, fully complete game.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely a roguelike.
Full Review: Explore a strange alien landscape as you gather crystals to repair your ship (recurring theme this year?). Don't be put off by the monochromatic display, this game hides a deep power management sub-game: players must manage gadgets, software, and armor suits that all use up power. Power generators are found in the dungeon but are rare and precious. In later levels, almost every new item forces you to re-evaluate and re-optimize your build. Player needs to find oxygen to survive, but this does not feel forced. Multiple damage types add another level of complexity, especially in deeper levels.

Completeness: 3 - Complete game
Aesthetics: 2 - Nice looking and functional UI, could use better feedback for the events
Fun: 3 - Fun, Challenging and gratifying
Innovation: 2 - Play as a monster, level up on staircase, skills tree
Scope: 2 - Nicely targetted
Roguelike: 3 - Yes, this is a roguelike
Full Review: You are a Wyrmling and... You Wanna Be The Wyrm. Bash weaklings and eat them, become older as you pass through the levels. Have fun!

Completeness: 2 - Lots of loose ends. Overall the game is fairly complete, but lacking in polish and balance. I maxed out my level about halfway through and most of the monsters repeat heavily.
Aesthetics: 1 - Decent sprite graphics, but I had to use Crtl and Alt and Shift for no good reason. I understand that the MOA engine is expandable, but damn those are some whacky controls.
Fun: 2 - Definitely fun, but way too grindy at the moment. I more or less stumbled over the end and I'm not sure what or how the ending is in anyway connected to anything else.
Innovation: 2 - A low 2, nothing that hasn't been seen before, but the game does a better job of capturing the feel of Wasteland/Fallout then most so it gets a 2
Scope: 3 - Definitely more that I expected from a 7DRL, though it is based on a pre-existing engine.
Roguelike: 3 - Definitely has all the standard RL elements, procedural generation, turn-based, perma-death and inventory management
Full Review: Escape from the Vault is a game with promise that lack polish. You are an inter-dimensional traveler and you have been captured in a post-apocalyptic dimension. Your mission is to escape from you cell in the heart of a mountain, rescue your faithful pet raptor-dog, find the military base and slay the fiend that is guarding the portal to your home dimension. The game doesn't describe any of this, but that's pretty much what I'm calling it. Decent graphics, horrible controls and a bit longer than it has content for. Hopefully the developer will continue work on this one.

Completeness: 3 - a complete, playable and fun little game. Didn't see any bugs or missing features.
Aesthetics: 2 - nice low-fi aesthetics, nothing too fancy but gets the job done and stays out of the way of the great gameplay.
Fun: 3 - I really like this game. It's a super focused design but with enough content (the different items you find in the dungeon) to still make for interesting and varied situations.
Innovation: 2 - it's pretty standard roguelike fare only boiled down to its essence - each enemy has 2hp, you have 10hp and heal 1 everything you go to a new level. The bulk of the gameplay is in the items you find in the dungeon, each of which is a consumable that doesn't something interesting (bombs of various patterns, change the level structure, teleport, etc).
Scope: 2 - a complete and well rounded game. Not particularly ambitious but just the right size for a 7drl.
Roguelike: 3 - pretty much a roguelike in every way, only reduced to its core essence.

Completeness: 3 - a complete game with a bit of a learning curve, but I've found no serious bugs.
Aesthetics: 3 - nice pixel art & pretty good controls.
Fun: 1 - maybe I just didn't get the game, but I haven't really done much except punch rabbits and trap them with me in the infinity. Didn't manage to get inside the building.
Innovation: 3 - the concept of drawing infinity is cute and interesting, but maybe could be presented a bit more clearly
Scope: 2 - a complete little game
Roguelike: 2 - real time gameplay, otherwise quite a normal roguelike with a twist.

Completeness: 3 - Not the most content rich game, but it does seem to be feature complete as advertised.
Aesthetics: 2 - Simple graphics, simple controls, both perfect for a game like this.
Fun: 2 - Fun for what it is, run around, kill some "k"s and dive deep.
Innovation: 1 - Nothing particularly new.
Scope: 1 - Pretty low on content and replayablity
Roguelike: 3 - Game consists only of the bare definition of a RL and nothing more.
Full Review: A very simple but clean roguelike. You are the @, you kill the K and ks, you get to the bottom of the dungeon and you get the treasure and escape. Nothing overly impressive, nothing particularly wrong or out-of-place.

Completeness: 1 - Even the author says it's incomplete; enemies barely fight back
Aesthetics: 1 - Very plain and just fine for the theme; deserves a low 2 except that h/l are swapped.
Fun: 1 - It's not much fun playing a game as incomplete as this, although firing torpedos isn't bad
Innovation: 2 - A new take on cross-sectional roguelikes, and projectiles that take time to reach their target are uncommon as a central mechanic
Scope: 2 - A low two, but it's easy to see where the author was going with it and that the plan was reasonable (even if it wasn't reached)
Roguelike: 2 - If it were more complete, I could see this being pure roguelike -- inventory management (of torpedoes, say) would have clinched it.
Full Review: I like the direction it's going.  This feels like it could be EmoSquid but actually playable if the author just puts a little more time into it.  The timing mechanics are fun (but don't make up for the absence of a game), and there's a lot of room for interesting terrain features at various depths.  I can see the vision, but it's just not reality yet.

Completeness: 2 - A few bugs
Aesthetics: 3 - I like the faded look; coupled with the slight blur, it feels like an old game system.  The dual control scheme is nice, and while it could be nicer I'd lump its flaws with Incompleteness. Sound and death splotches are satisfying.
Fun: 3 - I liked it quite a lot!  It would be better if it were harder (with all the fuel pickups available, it's just not much of a challenge) and if consequences of mechs coming online were worse (they're not that hard to beat), but it's a fun little game.
Innovation: 2 - Being able to redirect your power is novel; sadly, it doesn't prove to be terribly important to how the game is played
Scope: 2 - A very reasonable target
Full Review: A solid little game that does a good job with ranged combat.  The small dungeon levels are great for the 7DRL.  It's satisfying, blasting away enemies named after roguelike developers.  First person plural in the message log has an interesting feel.  Not charging a turn to divert power seems like a missed opportunity.

Completeness: 2 - Some pretty severe bugs.  The distance between you and an enemy actually affects whether you hit it, because your bolt has to touch the enemy's sprite to kill it.  Collision detection wreaks havoc on tactical maneuvering since you never know just what can kill you this turn.  Death on level start is a common problem.  ctrl/shift are detected a little unevenly.
Aesthetics: 3 - A gorgeous game and a great feel, interface bugs aside
Fun: 3 - A really challenging game that's short enough not to be frustrating even when it deserves it.  The tightest clock I've seen in a roguelike(like).  Lots of interesting gambles and little moments of puzzle.
Innovation: 3 - The turn-based platformer has been done, of course, but it's never been done in a way that proved that this is a game (and a sub-genre) you'd really want to play, and that could contain everything that roguelikes demand.  There's no single element here that counts as strictly innovative, but the particular combination is like nothing I've seen before -- and it actually works.
Roguelike: 2 - It's worth observing that while the jetpack is on, the game actually functions like a pure 4-way roguelike.  It's turn-based, has perma-death (and perma-loss of lesser kinds), has resource management, has a goal (a 'monopole' macguffin), has one-hp combat but no waiting.  Collisions are actually registered in real time, which is weird and counts as a bug.
Full Review: A really exciting offshoot of the roguelike genre, and one that I hope continues to bear fruit.  I'm serious -- there's a lot of depth here, and a lot of potential for some really hardcore strategic and tactical action.  This installment is a cute little puzzler, but it's got a strong strategic element and it's got a tight, minimalistic design that speaks well of the organizing vision.

Completeness: 3 - Fairly complete and polished.
Aesthetics: 2 - Message log obscures lower map area when you are near south border. Skeleton construction by 'wearing' parts sounds really silly. How do you wear a leg or an arm? Some spelling errors in descriptions.
Fun: 1 - Nice to try but filled with all kinds of instadeath and unbalance. After creating too good minion everything was wasted before I could react. Once I got hit for 148 points of damage. No joke.
Innovation: 2 - Minion creation itself badly apes Xenocide robot construction. However, enhancing bones with gems and metal is something new.
Scope: 2 - All right for 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - Roguelike indeed.
Full Review: Create minions from bones lying everywhere around. Killing a creature will give you one of its bones. You can enhance bones with gems and metal. Gets old fast and is hardly balanced. You can wipe out everything by yourself in the forest but in next area two goblin warriors if lucky can waste you and party of five skeletons.

Completeness: 2 - Really lacking in features but polished.
Aesthetics: 2 - Average.
Fun: 2 - Token system is easy to understand and actually could work work bigger game. A pity Emet is so short.
Innovation: 2 - Token system is unique way of implementing combat but it does not change gameplay significantly.
Scope: 1 - Below average. There are only two tiers of upgrades meaning you need 4 Met to see everything in one path.
Roguelike: 2 - A bare bones roguelike.
Full Review: This game serves one purpose: to try out token system. It works suprisingly well. Except that Emet has little to offer.

Completeness: 2 - Stable but requires polish especially in user interface.
Aesthetics: 2 - Okay in looks and keys but interface gives little to no feedback what is going on.
Fun: 1 - Mostly boring. Wander aimlessly and pick up $ glyphs. Beware of traps. According to readme there could be monsters but never found one.
Innovation: 1 - Not seeing anything new or unusual..
Scope: 2 - Seems fitting for a 7DRL.
Roguelike: 2 - No combat?
Full Review: After embarking on a flight to random planet from Gateway you can explore it for a bit and find loot worth money. You may want to take buddies too but thats about it. My character was beautiful but no idea what it does.

Completeness: 1 - Kinda busted, crashes on launch if you don't fix math.floor to int in the line in view.py reported in the crash. Generally aborts if you touch the keypad. Polish is kind of a moot point
Aesthetics: 2 - Functional hex-based graphics are enough to get a 2 in my book, and I'll judge the controls based on how they are intended to work under the assumption the PuTTY is messing them up on me.
Fun: 1 - Not a lot to do, can't target enemies, mostly you run around and try not to die.
Innovation: 2 - Hex is nice, the "hell" theme isn't used too often.
Scope: 1 - Kinda skimpy for a 7DRL
Roguelike: 2 - Some vague procedural content, but not really. Turn-based, permadeath.
Full Review: Currently, Hellmouth is a buggy mess. It doesn't seem to work without patching, and the control are either broken or my terminal is. The developer has plans to expand on the hex-based engine that drives this game (as can be seen in the more recent git commits) but the 7DRL entry is more of a technical success than an actual game.

Completeness: 2 - Seems feature complete, but lacks polish and balance. For example, traps don't seem to work.
Aesthetics: 2 - Decent tiles, but the controls are overly complicated for their need.
Fun: 2 - Simply not enough content to play for more than 5 minutes. Not actively annoying to play, but not to do either.
Innovation: 2 - The theme is new, as is using corpses to attract monsters.
Scope: 1 - Only one map, two enemies that aren't very distinct.
Roguelike: 3 - Procedural maps, turn-based and permadeath are all present, along with inventory management.
Full Review: You grab a knife, carrot and tracker and go hunt some rabbits. Dead rabbits attract wolves that kill you unless you find a rifle to kill them. The game is well put together but short and a bit clunky to control. Three times as much content and it would be a decent coffee-break RL.

Completeness: 1 - If you get the 7drl release tag instead of trunk, it works fine -- but it's clearly missing loads of intended features
Aesthetics: 2 - There's a lot of talk about doing hex in a roguelike without custom rendering, and in principle we seem to agree it's easy, but it's rarely actually done; it works pretty well and it does its job.
Fun: 1 - Attacking enemies with no objective is not terribly gripping
Innovation: 1 - The missing limb system, the missing "life path" system, or some content to take advantage of the hex layout (even some fov or interesting monsters), would separately deserve a 2 and jointly a 3, but here we have a single simple novelty with no supporting features
Scope: 1 - A bit of all-vs-all combat
Roguelike: 3 - Nothing to disqualify it; everything that's missing counts against completeness and scope
Full Review: There's clearly such a large amount of planned content missing (lifepath.py? A limb display?) that it doesn't hurt to call this one a marginal success as an entrant, but nothing worth looking at until its post-7DRL release.

Completeness: 3 - Polished.
Aesthetics: 3 - Good controls, fine looks.
Fun: 3 - This one is actually good sneak-em-up game. Praying seems to be only for flavor.
Innovation: 1 - Sneak mechanics have been done so many times. This actually plays like more forgiving version of Gruesome.
Scope: 2 - Just right for 7DRL.
Roguelike: 3 - Yes.
Full Review: Yet another sneaking rogue. It is a lie about you being significantly weaker than guards. You can waste a few soldiers reliably. The real problem in face to face combat is no hit point regeneration and healing salves give back only single one. There are some tricks to learn and backstabbing becomes reliable deal.

Completeness: 3 It feels feature complete for what it's trying to do.
Aesthetics: 2 The graphics are simple, but work well. Pleasing colours and effective use of sound. The keys do what you expect.
Fun: 2 A short and sweet game.
Innovation: 2 The focus of the game is the darkness mechanic which works well.
Scope: 2 What you'd expect from a 7DRL
Full Review: This is a delightfully effective survival horror game where your goal is to escape a house you just woke up in. "When all candles be out, all cats be gray" proves true as the house is very dark and you need a source of light to tell its deadly inhabitants from its not so deadly inhabitants and even the tools you need to escape. This is a libtcod game that uses the colour features for good and not for evil. Few but interesting monsters and short but sweet gameplay.

Game: I rule, you rule, we all rule old-school Hyrule
Completeness: 2 - Finished and polished, I wanted to give this a 3, but the little things like starting in an unwinnable state and the way that long range enemies can pillar dance you, even when you also have a long range weapon annoys me
Aesthetics: 3 - Good graphics, simple controls, only improvement I would like to see is more visual feedback or quicker access to the "look" information.
Fun: 3 - An addictive but enjoyable game.
Innovation: 3 - The "win" condition makes the while game feel like a game of capture the flag.
Scope: 3 - Low 3, but definitely more than i would expect from a 7DRL project.
Roguelike: 3 - Another low 3, definitely has all the features of a roguelike (Procedural content, Permadeath, turn-based, inventory management) but it plays differently that most RLs I've played.
Full Review: Definitely another competitor for best in show, from what I've seen. Try to claim the Hyrulean crown by slaughtering monsters and reclaiming artifacts, but other claimants race against you. This is one title I'll be keeping an eye on, while it is good in it's current state, it will be interesting to see how this one develops.

Completeness: 2 - The crashing bug (when monsters can't path to you) makes it hard to play through.  Big props on having high scores.
Aesthetics: 2 - Looks good enough.  Nothing exceptional. j/k are reversed, which is irritating, but since it has 4-way movement the arrows are serviceable.
Fun: 2 - It's fun to figure out optimal play, but once you settle into a routine there aren't many decisions to make.
Innovation: 1 - Nothing new here; with a bit more work, the stamina system could qualify for a 2 or a 3, but fighting an enemy is like picking up a health pack right now.
Scope: 2 - Pretty standard 7DRL, maybe a little short of 2 but it has some nice polish that puts it over.
Roguelike: 3 - Clearly.
Full Review: A brilliant finish for a project that was, by the author's account, doomed to failure in the middle of the week.  There are many, many entries less deserving of being called 7DRL successes than this.  Congrats to the author for that.

Completeness: 2 - Has success and failure, but as author notes the current system renders the depth component less interesting.  I'd also have liked to see some interesting ocean floor fractal rather than just the pillar like islands.
Aesthetics: 1 - Look is stark. Props for vi-keys, but the h&l are backwards.  When you are killed hitting any key but y will immediately quit the game, for example, accidentally hitting an extra movement key.  Maybe only allow y/n.
Fun: 1 - The enemies don't seem to pose much threat other than my laziness.  The requirement to move to change my facing feels more frustrating than an interesting tactical component.
Innovation: 3 - Quite a few interesting ideas were tried at once here.  There is the 3d view with the two half planes (though I worry this will prove myopic if it were actually necessary.  The slow torpedos and facing requirments are also interesting to explore.
Scope: 1 - If we ignore the depth map, it becomes an @ on map level scope.
Roguelike: 2 - It is intended to be a tactical combat game, so I could see this easily moving into the 3 column, but with its level of completion it is hard to say it can overcome the fact the skin is so non-roguelike.
Full Review: A very interesting take on submarine combat.  It attempts to address some interesting ideas, such as proper diving (with 3d slice viewing), slow torpedos, and facing.  However, it hasn't been developed far enough to really judge if these features are good things or not.

Completeness: 3 - Does appear to achieve all it set out to.
Aesthetics: 2 - I love the pixel art look and the ambient music.  But the realm of user interface is very painful.  Targeting is very unclear, so I'm not sure if I'm actually attacking someone or not.  The combat is hearbeat based, but I don't have a good sense of heartbeat from the status messages.  Pop-up menus are dangerous when one is Runaway, which doesn't have a confirmation.  I kept clicking everywhere but myself to try and get going in the game.  Pressing keys to proc the traits didn't give feedback, so I'd never be sure if they actually took or not.
Fun: 1 - The look and sound makes me want to like it, but I just get increasingly frustrated at my characters behaviour.  I don't feel I have any control in the combat as to what it does.
Innovation: 2 - The trait based leveling system is one I like and wish I could have explored further.  The hybrid turn/realtime is an innovation for roguelikes, but I didn't like it in Neverwinter Nights either.
Scope: 2 - The feaeture set is quite good for a 7drl.
Roguelike: 1 - Combat in disconnected rooms really makes it DND like (note, not D&D)  While rooms are randomized, I'm not sure about the topology (which is the more interesting part) the starting ruins at least seems to always have the same topology.
